args:
To further his own selfish goals, Finlorda agreed
to aid Aurelius. After confessing this, he gives
the prince a letter from his father, in which he
asks the prince to find the thoughts he has
entrusted to the Sacred Tree.
How? How could you do such a thing?
How could your father commit\nsuch a profane act?
Because he had a dream.\nA mad and beautiful dream.
Though nary a shadow of his former self\nremains, my father was once a progressive\nking worthy of great respect.
Like myself, he promoted the active\nresearch of magic in an effort to\nstrengthen our faerie bodies.
The results were brilliant; even the power\nof metamorphosis I make use of now is\nbased upon research from that time.
And one of the keys for the development\nof this magic was research conducted on\nthe royal family of Alberia.

The very same. Finlorda was fascinated by
the dragonblood which allowed your family
to shapeshift, and bent all of his will to
uncovering the mysteries behind it.
Which is why he accepted our father's\nrequest and agreed to replace his child.
In doing so, he could investigate the body\nof a royal and plumb the mysteries of the\ndragonblood to his heart's content.
He could then use what knowledge he\ngained as part of his own research.
Quite so. However, at some point he\nbetrayed his cause, gave up his research,\nand attempted to seal it all away.
This about-face confounded the ruling\ncouncil at the center of our polity, and\nmade my father's downfall an inevitability.
It was incomprehensible behavior,\nand foolish beyond reckoning.
Yet I feel as though I might understand\nyour father's feelings.
Perhaps he regrets his perversion\nof mana's natural order.

A line of thinking befitting the Auspex.
However, obeisance to the natural order
of a thing is an idea which comes only
from those content with the status quo.
The weak, though? They must resist the\ngiven stricture. They must fight to achieve\nwhat they desire.
You are of the same mind,\nare you not, Nedrick?
Finlorda, did you accept my father's\nproposal in order to research dragonblood?
Yes. I burned to know the secret of\nshapeshifting, and thought the answer\nmight lie in the bodies of Alberian royals.
I was a man possessed by my own hubris\nin those days; enraptured both by my own\nability and the faerie arts I developed.

With that magic, I believed I could shore
up our natural flaws as faeries and change
every rule underpinning the very workings
of the world!

And thus did I commit myself to
performing the art. But I had no proof
that a body made by using the Other's
flesh would be a stable vessel...
Which is why you sent Notte to Alberia.

When a body grows beyond infancy, the
mana within becomes more active—and
with that increased activity came a danger
of the Other's flesh raging out of control.
So you thought I might...go berserk?
Yes. Through Notte, I could keep an eye\non you in secret and be ready in case any\nproblems arose.
Fortunately, no such catastrophe ever\ncame about. Nevertheless, my actions\nwere unconscionable.
I wanted to learn what the possible danger\na child wrought from the flesh of that devil\nmight pose to the royal family.
And I was also curious how the child\nitself would grow and react to the\nworld at large.
My desire to know such answers led me\nto disregard all bounds of decency.
I am most sorry, Notte.\nI am most sorry, {player_name}.
Was the literature you referred to in order\nto study the Other's body truly so reliable?

It was a text written a millennium ago by
a princess who broke her wings and whose
body stopped growing—a princess who
never returned to the Faerie Kingdom.
This individual personally bore witness\nto the birth of the Other. So yes, I believe\nthe work to be exceedingly credible.
Then she was there the moment the Other\ncame forth from a gate to another world?
The history you know is not the truth.
The princess wrote this of the Other:
＂The Other is an existence brought about\nby the distortion caused when the bonds\nbetween human and dragon are shaken.＂
Oh, this is folly! Everyone knows the Other\nwas something summoned by humans to\nfight AGAINST the dragons!
Indeed, what you say goes against both\nIlian scripture and all known history.
You need not understand everything at\nthis moment, but I would ask that you\nbear the information in mind.
And with that, my tale comes to an end.\nBut before we part, I would give you this.
One Aurelius wrote for you here in the\nFaerie Kingdom at the time of your birth.
He entrusted it to me when we vowed\nnever to reveal the secret of your birth.
He bade me pass it on if ever you\nwere to come to my door.
That is my father's handwriting,\nas well as his seal.
All right. I'm going to open it.
There is no need to convey the contents\nto us if you are unwilling.
The letter is from father to son, after all.
Actually, I'd like you all to hear it.
I...I don't know if I can take whatever\nmight be inside on my own.
＂My dear son. If you are reading this,\nyou have come to the Faerie Kingdom.＂
＂And in that case, I am no longer alive.＂
＂Know that my heart swells with pride to\nsee you grown enough to make such a\nlong and arduous journey.＂

＂Though you may be alone, I hope in my
heart that you are surrounded by friends
and comrades of quality—ones in whom
you can place your undying trust.＂
＂My son, I ask you not to blame Finlorda;\nI am the genesis of the events to which\nyou will have been made privy.＂
＂Though yours is a life born from my own\nselfishness, I beg you keep one thing ever\nin your heart: You are my precious son.＂
＂I ought to have told you all this myself\nfrom the beginning, but the secret compact\nI agreed to forbade it.＂
＂Still, I believed that one day you would\ncome to the land of the faeries seeking\nthe truth about yourself.＂
＂As such, I have left my thoughts\nbehind in the Sacred Tree.＂
＂If you find it in your heart to forgive me,\nthen I beg of you to go there and\nexperience my feelings for yourself.＂
＂From the bottom of my heart, I pray for\nyour happiness, your health, and your\nlong and productive life.＂
He left thoughts in the tree?\nWhat does that mean?
Just what is with this Sacred Tree,\nanyway? Gatov mentioned it earlier, too.
It is a colossal, ancient thing tall enough\nto pierce the very heavens themselves.\nYou will find it in the north of the kingdom.

Faeries have worshipped it since ancient
times. We have partaken of its blessings,
and in turn fought to ensure that its power
was never misused.
And some of Father's memories\nawait us there?
So it would seem, though I am equally in\nthe dark as to the details.
The Sacred Tree holds an immeasurable\namount of mana, and has given rise to\nmiracles far beyond human ken.
And now, it seems Aurelius has entrusted\nsomething very precious to it.
If you intend to go to the Sacred Tree,\nI will accompany you.
Permit me to accompany you as well.
Oh, you KNOW you ain't going without me!
Look, can you just give me a little time?\nI need to get my thoughts in order about\nwhat I should do next.
I'm all right, Zena. Don't worry. Honestly,\nthere's a part of me that feels relieved\nto finally know the truth.
It's just...it's a lot, you know? I need to\ncool my head for a bit and think.
